1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 52 (1989) 113 -127 113 FORMATION AND REACTIVITIES OF FORMATE SPECIES ON A POTASSIUM-MODIFIED OSMIUM/ALUMINA CATALYST: AN INFRARED SPECTROSCOPIC STUDY YILU FU , LEONORE KRAUS and HELMUT KNOZINGER** Institut fur Physikalische Chemie, Universitat Munchen, Sophienstrasse 11, 8000 Munich 2 (F. R. G.) Summary The formation of formate species on a K Os/Al^Oa catalyst was followed by IR spectroscopy, and the reactivity of the surface formate in HI and water atmospheres was studied. The results strongly suggest that the formate is an intermediate in the water-gas shift reaction. A catalytic cycle is postulated in which bicarbonate, formate and hydroxyl surface species are involved. The formation of the formate from CO by reaction with OH" is presumably the slowest step in the cycle. Introduction In a previous paper [1] we have described the preparation and charac- teristics of a potassium-modified osmium/alumina catalyst, which was obtained by impregnation from aqueous solution of the alumina support by a potassium osmyi precursor compound, namely Ki[Os02(OH)4]. Reduc- tion in flowing H; at 670 K led to partial reduction of the osmium (average oxidation state +0.6) to Os , accompanied by metal aggregation (average particle size 1.8 nm). On adsorption of CO, Os^CO),: surface complexes could be detected as well. The potassium should be present in this catalyst as KzO (or perhaps KOH, if water vapour was not excluded). It was also demonstrated that bicarbonate, carbonate and formate species were formed on this material when CO was adsorbed, and we had speculated that the formate species might possibly be an intermediate in the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction on this catalyst. The generation of formate species on adsorption of carbon oxides on oxide surfaces and supported metals has been widely documented in the literature. The available data have been reviewed by Busca and Lorenzelli [2] and by Deluzarche et al. [3]. Infrared vibrational data of surface formate *0n leave from: Department of Modern Chemistry, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, Anhui, China. **Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/89/$3.60 Eisevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 114 species were compiled by Busca and Lorenzelli [2] and by Donaldson et al. [4]. A very detailed IR study of the generation of formate species from CO on ZnO was recently published by Hussain and Sheppard [5]. On alu- mina supports, formates have also been generated during adsorption of carbon oxides [2, 6 - 8]. It has been shown that CO directly reacts with surface OH groups on alumina [8]. KaCOa/A^Oa is known as a WGS cata- lyst, and formation of formate species on this material was clearly dem- onstrated by Amenomiya and coworkers [9,10] and by Kantschewa et al. [11]. The formate was coordinated to K* sites in a bidentate configuration on a catalyst containing 12 wt.% I^COa [11]. It is interesting to note that alkali-containing Pd/SiO; catalysts (pre- pared from MaPdCU with M = Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs) produced the formate ion on adsorption of CO [12], while it was absent on alkali-free Pd/SiO;. It was suggested that alkali chlorides were present in these materials which retain water strongly. Formate formation was thus thought to be due to reaction of CO with the water retained in the system [3]. Recently, formate species have also been detected on a potassium-containing Rh/A^Os cata- lyst when CO was adsorbed in the presence of hydrogen [13]. Intermediate formation of CO; was suggested to be responsible for the generation of the formate. Formate species have been considered as intermediates for a variety of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions of carbon oxides [3,14], including the WGS reaction [9 -11,14 - 26]. In the present paper, we report on the generation of formate and bicarbonate species from CO and COa on the mentioned potassium-modified osmium/alumina catalyst, and on the reac- tivity of these surface species in various atmospheres with the goal to clarify their possible role as intermediates in the WGS reaction. Some other catalyst preparations (see [1]), which contain either osmium only or potassium only, were also investigated for comparison purposes. Experimental Catalyst preparation and pretreatment The 'y-AlaOa support was produced by calcination in air of Condea Alumina Pural SB (boehmite type) at 1023 K for 20 h. It had a BET surface area of 140 m2 g~1. The potassium osmate compound K2[Os02(OH)4] was impregnated from aqueous solution under N3, the excess water being removed by evacuation at room temperature. The material was then dried at 373 K. The details of the preparation of this catalyst, as well as of several other materials which will be used in this work for reference purposes, are described in the previous paper [1]. The catalyst precursors and the catalyst compositions are summarized in Table 1. The notation used for the various catalysts, namely Aa, B, C and D, are the same as in [1]. The pure support material 7-A1203 will be designated E throughout this paper. All catalysts were stored in sealed ampoules under N3 and exposed to air 115 TABLE 1 Composition of the catalysts Sample Precursor Os content K content(wt.%) (wt.%) Aa B C D E Ki[Os02(OH)4]OS3(CO)i2-K2C03 US3(CO)i2KiCOa T-AliOa 4.2 1.74 1.6 0.5 1.6 only during the short period required to prepare self-supporting wafers for IR experiments (vide infra). The catalysts were reduced in situ m the IR cell m flowing Ha (50 cm3 min"1) at 673 K for 60 min. They were then evacuated and adsorption experiments were thereafter carried out. Gases H;, CO, COa and N3 were Linde products with a nominal purity of 99.997%. The gases were further dried and deoxygenated by passing them through appropriate Oxisorb cartridges. Instrumentation and procedure IR spectra were recorded at a resolution of 5.3 cm"1 on a Perkin- Elmer 580 B spectrophotometer; the wavenumber accuracy was 2 cm"1. Self-supporting wafers (10 mg cm"2) were obtained by pressing the powder at 200 kg cm"2. These wafers were mounted m an IR cell (CaFa windows) specially designed for in situ treatments and chemisorption experiments [27]. The cell system consisted of an IR transparent part which was kept at room temperature, and a heating zone. The wafers could be quickly moved in situ between cell and heating zone by means of a greaseless mag- netic system. Thus, in situ treatments at elevated temperatures under static conditions or in a flow of gas can easily be carried out prior to recording the spectra at room temperature. When the transformation of surface species was to be studied at elevated temperatures as a function of time, the sample was held in the heating zone under controlled pressure and temperature conditions for a predetermined period of time and quenched to room temperature in the IR transparent part of the cell, where spectra were recorded and absorbance for the various surface species determined. This procedure could be repeated several times and permitted kinetic measure- ments to be carried out, when absorbances at characteristic frequencies were determined as a function of reaction time, A(t). These A(t) values were normalized to A(0), the absorbance at time zero, for surface species which were consumed during the surface reaction, and to Aoo, the final 116 absorbance, for surface species which were built up during the reaction period. When studying the reactivity of surface formate in vacuum, H; or HzO atmosphere, the rate of consumption of the formate was assumed to be first order in surface concentration of the formate. Results Adsorption of carbon monoxide It was shown in [1] that the catalyst A was partially reduced under the reduction conditions chosen in this study, namely flowing Ha at 673 K for 60 min. Metal aggregation did occur, and mononuclear Os2'*' species were present as well. The potassium probably exists as K^O or KOH. Figure 1 shows the background IR spectrum of the A specimen after this reduction procedure in the frequency range 2200 to 1100 cm"1. No characteristic absorptions can be seen after the reduction procedure described above. Adsorption of CO at 573 K led to the development of two broad overlapping 117 2000 1800 1600 Wovenumber / cm 1400 1200 Fig. l. IR spectra of CO adsorption on catalyst Ag. As shown previously, these bands are characteristic for CO adsorp- tion on metallic osmium, and may contain contributions from Os^CO)^ surface complexes as well [1]. It was also shown previously [I], that CO adsorption on this reduced catalyst at temperatures below 423 K gave absorption bands characteristic of the bicarbonate HC03, namely at 1655, 1432, and 1230 cm"1, and of a CO2 species at 1335 cm"1. This behaviour has been reproduced in the present study. On adsorption of CO at 573 K, spectrum (2) in Fig. 1 was obtained, which clearly shows the bands of HCO^ and of CO^. In addition, however, at this higher temperature bands at 2900, 1597, 1395 and 1377 cm"1 can be discerned, which can undoubtedly be attributed to a surface formate HCOi [2,4]. The assignment was confirmed by adsorption of CO on a deuterated surface, thus leading to the formation of DCO; (2187, 1594 and 1348 cm"1). The observed band positions of HCO;, namely the v(C H) band at 2900 cm"1 and the band splitting between asymmetric (1597 cm-1) and symmetric (1377 cm"1) C 0 stretching modes of 220 cm"1, suggest a bridging formate adsorbed on the 7-A12O3 support surface [1, 2, 28]. This is in contrast with our earlier work [II], which had dem- onstrated that formate species were coordinated to K+ in a catalyst derived from K^COy on Al203. However, this latter catalyst contained 7 wt.% K, while the present material A contains only 1.74 wt.% (see Table 1). When the catalyst exhibiting spectrum (2) in Fig. 1 was evacuated at 473 K, the characteristic bands of HCOs and COi immediately disap- peared (Fig. 1, spectrum (3)) and the only remaining bands were those of 118 CO adsorbed on osmium metal and of the formate species, indicating the relative stability of this species and the lability of bicarbonate and COa species. These experiments clearly demonstrate that the initial surface species to be formed on CO adsorption are the HCO^ and CO; species at tem- peratures below about 423 K, while the HCO^ species only develops at increasing temperatures in the presence of CO. As a consequence, it is possible to produce HCO;} and CO; species selectively at low temperature. A possible transformation of either of these two species into HCO^ at higher temperature can then be followed by measuring the absorbances of characteristic absorption bands as a function of time. The band at 1230 cm"1 of HCOa, the band at 1395 cm"1 of HCOa and that at 1335 cm"1 of CO; have been chosen for these experiments. At 423 K in the presence of 50 torr CO (1 torr = 133.3 N m"2) only the bands of HCO^ and CO; are present. When the sample was then brought to 473 K, the absorbance of HCO; decreased and that at 1395 cm"1 of HCOa appeared in the spectrum, while the 1335 cm"1 band of CO; remained constant in intensity. The latter correlation is almost linear, indicating a direct conversion of HCOa into HCOa presumably via reduction by CO. This modified behaviour must be related to the presence of H;, which can not only act as a second reducing agent but which can also dissociate on the metal. This behaviour compares well with the formate formation from CO or CO + Ha, and indicates again that a reducing agent is required to transform HCO:} into the HCO; species. Reactivity of formate on other catalysts For comparison purposes a series of analogous experiments was carried out, using catalysts B through D and the alumina support (E). The rate and pseudo-rate constants for the three reaction classes, namely thermal decomposition, reaction with H; and with HaO, are summarized in Table 3. Comparison with the data of Table 2 clearly shows that formate reactivities were the highest for all the reactions on catalyst Ag, whose behaviour has been described in detail throughout this paper. Closer inspection of the data of Table 3, namely those of formate reactivities in H 2 and H^O, seem to indicate that osmium enhances the reactivities relative to the pure support and so does potassium, although to a lesser extent. Discussion The formation of bicarbonate species HCOs on oxide surfaces on adsorption of COy. has been reported repeatedly [29, 30], and can be de- scribed as a reaction involving nucleophilic surface OH~ groups: COi + OH-(a) > HC03(a) (5) This reaction seems to occur on catalyst Ag as well. Although the direct formation of HCO^ during CO adsorption has been reported [3, 5, 8,11, 124 33], this reaction did not occur on the freshly reduced catalyst Aa. The bicarbonate HCO^ (and some fairly unreactive CO^) was the dominant surface species formed during CO adsorption, presumably via intermediate CC>2 followed by reaction (5) above. Hence, CO must initially react with surface oxygen : CO + 0(a) > COi (6) At higher temperatures, the formate HCO;; is also formed during CO ad- sorption but not at all when CO; is adsorbed. This clearly suggests that the formate is a secondary product on this surface, produced via reduction of the primary chemisorption product HCO^. This is supported by the fact that HC03 formed from CO; is immediately transformed into HCOz if the material is exposed to H 2 at about 473 K and higher temperatures. During CO adsorption, CO itself acts as the reducing agent: HC03-(a) + CO > HCO^a) + CO^ (7) HCO^a) + HI > HCO^a) + H^O (8) The reduction of bicarbonates to formate has been reported for various oxide systems [3,8,21,22,34,35]. Exposure to H; led to additional formate formation when C02 was present: CO^a) + H(a) > HCO^a) (9) where the H atom may be formed via dissociative adsorption of H; on the osmium metal component of the catalyst. If water vapour was present during CO adsorption, the bicarbonate did not form but rather formate was produced directly. This can be inter- preted in two ways. Either CO reacts directly with H20(a) retained on the surface: CO + HsO + O2 -(a) > HCO^a) + OH-(a) (10) This reaction would presumably be similar to that proposed for alkali- modified Pd/SiOa catalysts [3,12] as mentioned in the introduction. The alternative would be the initial dissociative chemisorption of H^O which would lead to a more highly hydroxylated surface: HsO + O2 -(a) > 20H-(a) (11) CO + OH--(a) > HCO^a) (12) The formate species once produced on the catalyst surface is rather stable thermally. Thermal decomposition in vacuum becomes measurable only at temperatures around 573 K and higher. The decomposition presumably involves formation of CO: HCO^a) > CO + OH-(a) (13) the reverse reaction of step (12). 125 In the presence of H; or HzO, significant reactivities of the surface formate were observed. The reaction with Hz seems to produce CO as a product, which is at least intermediately adsorbed on the osmium metal before it desorbs or before it is hydrogenated to methane: HCO^a) + H; > CO + HzO + H-(a) (14) Speculatively an additional route may consist in the reverse reaction of the dehydrogenation of formic acid which is known to proceed via a formate intermediate [14]: HCO^a) + H; > HCOOH + H-(a) (15) The osmium metal and the mononuclear Os* + complexes which have been shown to be present m the catalyst may well be involved in related redox steps. Finally, particularly high reactivity was observed of the formate when water was present. One would expect that the reaction of the surface for- mate and HaO would follow the reverse route of steps (8) and (5), namely: HCO^a) + HzO > HCOi(a) + H; (16) and HCO^a) CO; + OH-(a) (17) It appears, however, that step (17) is so fast under the experimental con- ditions that only the overall reaction, namely the decrease of the sur- face concentration of HCO^, can be observed with no intermediate HCO^ detected: HCO^a) + HiO > CO; + Hz + OH-(a) (18) The experimental results indicate that the surface formate HCOz can in fact be considered as an intermediate of the WGS reaction on catalyst Aa, whereas experimental evidence could not be obtained under the chosen reaction conditions for any adsorbed hydrogenation products of the for- mate, such as formyi or methoxy species, which might be considered as intermediates in methanation or methanoi synthesis [3]. A perhaps simplified catalytic cycle for the present catalyst Aa may tentatively be written as shown in Scheme 1. In this scheme, step (3) (which corresponds to reaction (17)) is undoubtedly the fastest step in the cycle, OH-la) ^- ' HC03 (a) ^COz Scheme 1. 126 since the HCO: species could not be detected although it must be an inter- mediate, based on the principle of microscopic reversibility, since HCOa has been shown to be formed via the reverse reaction (5). From the data de- scribed above and summarized in Table 2, it may seem that step (1) (cor- responding to reaction (12)) is the slowest step in the cycle under the present experimental conditions, the more so as the water partial pressure which determines the rate of step (2) was very low in our experiments. The comparison of the kinetic data obtained for the reference catalysts as summarized in Table 3, permit some qualitative and tentative conclusions regarding the role played by the osmium and potassium in the various surface reactions. The thermal stability of the formate in vacuum does not seem to be significantly influenced by the metal nor the potassium. However, the formate reactivities toward HI and HzO are drastically en- hanced by the osmium as compared to the pure 'y-A^Oa support. The reasons, which are not clear, may however be related to increased rates of H; dissociation and H-atom recombination. The dissociation of the water molecule might also be influenced by the metal. Moreover, the mono- nuclear osmium complexes 0s*"1" which are present after reduction of the catalyst precursors, may be involved in the redox steps occurring in the catalytic cycle. The question of whether hydrogen spills over from the metal to the support where the intermediates are located, or migration of formates to the metal support interface occurs remains unresolved and cannot be discussed on the basis of our present results. The role of potassium is complex, in that it seems to enhance formate reactivities relative to the pure -y-AlaOa support in the absence of osmium, while it attenuates the effect of osmium when both components are present. Conclusions The kinetic study by IR spectroscopy of the behaviour of surface bicarbonate and formate species on a K Os/AlaOa catalyst renders the role of these two surface species as intermediates in the WGS reaction highly probable. The formation of the formate from CO is presumably the slowest step in the catalytic cycle.
